OieqR0y7.title: Ultrafine NiO particles induce cytotoxicity in vitro by cellular uptake and subsequent Ni(II) release.
OieqR0y7.abstract: Nickel oxide (NiO) is one of the important industrial materials used in electronic substrates and for ceramic engineering. Advancements in industrial technology have enabled the manufacture of ultrafine NiO particles. On the other hand, it is well-known that nickel compounds exert toxic effects. The toxicity of nickel compounds is mainly caused by nickel ions (Ni(2+)). However, the ion release properties of ultrafine NiO particles are still unclear. In the present study, the influences of ultrafine NiO particles on cell viability were examined in vitro to obtain fundamental data for the biological effects of ultrafine green NiO and ultrafine black NiO. Ultrafine NiO particles showed higher cytotoxicities toward human keratinocyte HaCaT cells and human lung carcinoma A549 cells than fine NiO particles and also showed higher solubilities in culture medium (Dulbecco's modified Eagle's medium supplemented with 10% fetal bovine serum) than fine NiO particles. In particular, the concentration of Ni(2+) released into the culture medium by ultrafine green NiO was 150-fold higher than that released by fine green NiO. The concentrations of Ni(2+) released by both types of NiO particles in an aqueous solution containing amino acids were remarkably higher than those released by NiO particles in water. Moreover, we prepared a uniform and stable dispersion of ultrafine black NiO in culture medium and examined its influence on cell viability in comparison with that of NiCl(2), a soluble nickel compound. A medium exchange after 6 h of exposure resulted in a loss of cytotoxicity in the cells exposed to NiCl(2), whereas cytotoxicity was retained in the cells exposed to NiO. Transmission electron microscope observations revealed uptake of both ultrafine and fine NiO particles into HaCaT cells. Taken together, the present results suggest that the intracellular Ni(2+) release could be an important factor that determines the cytotoxicity of NiO. Ultrafine NiO is more cytotoxic than fine NiO in vitro.

fIV49YWY.title: Expression of cytokine-induced neutrophil chemoattractant in rat lungs by intratracheal instillation of nickel oxide nanoparticles.
fIV49YWY.abstract: Since nanoparticles easily agglomerate to form larger particles, it is important to maintain the size of their agglomerates at the nano-level to evaluate the harmful effect of the nanoparticles. We prevented agglomeration of nickel oxide nanoparticles by ultrasound diffusion and filtration, established an acute exposure model using animals, and examined inflammation and chemokine expression. The mass median diameter of nickel oxide nanoparticle agglomerates suspended in distilled water for intratracheal instillation was 26 nm (8.41 nm weighted average surface primary diameter). Male Wistar rats received intratracheal instillation of nickel oxide nanoparticles at 0.1 mg (0.33 mg/kg) or 0.2 mg (0.66 mg/kg), and were dissected 3 days, 1 week, 1 month, 3 months, and 6 months after the instillation. The control group received intratracheal instillation of distilled water. Three chemokines (cytokine-induced neutrophil chemoattractant-1 (CINC-1), CINC-2alphabeta, and CINC-3) in the lung tissue and bronchoalveolar lavage fluid (BALF) were determined by quantitative measurement of protein by ELISA. Both CINC-1 and CINC-2alphabeta concentration was elevated from day 3 to 3 months in lung tissue and from day 3 to 6 months in BALF. On the other hand, CINC-3 was elevated on day 3 in both lung tissue and BALF, and then decreased. The total cell and neutrophil counts in BALF were increased from day 3 to 3 months. In lung tissue, infiltration of mainly neutrophils and alveolar macrophages was observed from day 3 to 6 months in alveoli. These results suggest that CINC was involved in lung injury by nickel oxide nanoparticles.

3dNx1p45.title: A determination method of pristine multiwall carbon nanotubes in rat lungs after intratracheal instillation exposure by combustive oxidation-nondispersive infrared analysis.
3dNx1p45.abstract: This paper describes a method for determination of multiwall carbon nanotubes (MWCNTs) in rat lungs after intratracheal instillation exposure. The MWCNTs were quantitatively decomposed to CO(2) by combustive oxidation and were then determined by non-dispersive infrared analysis. Samples were pretreated by acid digestion, muffle ashing and in situ preheating to remove interferences due to coexisting biological carbon from the lung tissue sample, while preserving the MWCNTs as in its their original form. The preservation was confirmed by transmission electron microscopic observation of the pretreated samples of exposed lung tissues and by the fact that the recoveries of MWCNTs spiked to the lung tissues were close to 100%. The detection limit for MWCNTs obtained by the proposed method was 0.30 μg and the repeatability as expressed by the relative standard deviation was 5.6% (n=4). The method was sufficiently sensitive and precise to apply to real samples of rat lung to investigate the in vivo persistence of intratracheally instilled MWCNTs. To our knowledge, this is the first report of this type of sample pretreatment and direct determination of pristine MWCNTs without modification or tagging. Conventional indirect methods use tagging with other compounds or metal impurities in the CNTs for detection, and the detachment of these tags can increase uncertainties in the determination of the CNTs. The tags can also change how the CNTs persist in vivo, which can lead to an incorrect understanding of the persistence of pristine CNTs in vivo.

0ZIgoFsw.title: Comparative pulmonary toxicity study of nano-TiO2 particles of different sizes and agglomerations in rats: Different short- and long-term post-instillation results
0ZIgoFsw.abstract: Two intratracheal instillation experiments with nano-size titanium dioxide (TiO 2 ) particles of different sizes and agglomerations were conducted in rats to compare the biological responses induced by the different particles. In experiment 1, 5 mg/kg of nano-TiO 2 particles of different primary sizes was intratracheally instilled in rats. In experiment 2, a similar procedure was followed with 5 mg/kg of nano-TiO 2 particles of the same primary sizes but different agglomerations in liquid. Following the instillations, body and lung weight measurements, bronchoalveolar fluid (BALF) cells and inflammatory biomarkers assessment, and histopathological evaluations of the lungs and other tissues were conducted. Pulmonary inflammatory responses until 1 week post-instillation differed among the TiO 2 particle-exposed groups: that is, smaller particles induced greater inflammation in the short-term observations. With regard to the long-term effects (>1 week post-instillation), however, pulmonary inflammation remarkably recovered in all the TiO 2 particle-exposed groups, with no differences between the groups regardless of particle size. On the other hand, no clear relationship was observed between the TiO 2 particle-exposed groups with different agglomerations but the same primary size. These findings suggest that different evaluations can be derived on the basis of the observations up to 1 week post-instillation and those after 1 month post-instillation. In most of the current studies, the relationship between pulmonary responses and instilled particle sizes has been discussed only on the basis of the 24 h post-instillation results, which could be a misleading evaluation. Consequently, our findings indicate that both short- and long-term effects should be evaluated when assessing the toxicity of nanoparticles based on the results of intratracheal instillation studies. Keywords TiO 2 Nanoparticle Particle size Intratracheal instillation Hazard assessment 1 Introduction Engineered nanomaterials are being used widely with the development of nanotechnologies. However, there is growing concern regarding the risks to humans and the environment due to exposure during the production, use, consumption, and disposal of these products. In general, the term “nanomaterial” refers to a material with one, two, or three dimensions of roughly 1–100 nm in size and its aggregates ( ISO, 2008 ). Although these materials are expected to fulfill various novel functions, the fact that their potential toxicities and the underlying mechanisms cannot be predicted by applying the present knowledge, because of their extremely small sizes, is a cause for concern. For example, nano-size titanium dioxide (TiO 2 ) particles have greatly increased functions as catalysts due to the increase in surface area per particle weight. Further, they can be used as cosmetics due to increased clarity. On the other hand, the pulmonary responses induced by inhaled nanoparticles are considered to be greater than micron-sized particles because of the increased surface area per particle weight. Moreover, inhaled nanoparticles, after deposition in the lungs, largely escape the alveolar macrophage surveillance and gain greater access to the pulmonary interstitium by translocation from alveolar spaces through the epithelium ( Donaldson et al., 2001; Oberdörster et al., 2005 ). Oberdörster et al. (1992) and Renwick et al. (2004) have reported that rats intratracheally instilled with ultrafine (nano-size) TiO 2 particles have greater pulmonary inflammatory responses than those intratracheally instilled with fine (submicron-size) TiO 2 particles. Further, when the instilled doses were expressed in terms of particle surface area, the responses induced by the ultrafine and fine TiO 2 particles fell on the same dose–response curve ( Oberdörster, 2000; Oberdörster et al., 2005; Donaldson et al., 2001 ). They therefore concluded that the greater inflammatory responses observed were due to the large surface area of the ultrafine TiO 2 particles. By intratracheal instillation studies of poorly soluble, low toxicity particles other than TiO 2 (such as carbon black and polystyrene latex) in rats, Brown et al. (2000, 2001) and Duffin et al. (2007) found that smaller particles produce greater pulmonary inflammatory responses. Some inhalation studies have been conducted to examine the relationship between the pulmonary responses and particle size. Following a 12-week inhalation study of rats exposed to nano-size (20 nm) and submicron-size (250 nm) TiO 2 particles, pulmonary inflammation was observed only the group exposed to the nano-size TiO 2 particles ( Oberdörster et al., 1994 ). Bermudez et al. (2004) reported that nano-TiO 2 particles produce stronger inflammatory responses than micron-sized TiO 2 particles, by comparing the results of a 13-week inhalation study with nano- and micron-TiO 2 particles. These researchers suggested that the differences in the response were due to the differences in the surface area of the inhaled TiO 2 particles. Further, Tran et al. (2000) have reported that the responses of rats exposed to TiO 2 and BaSO 4 particles fell on the same dose–response curve when the dose was expressed in terms of particle surface area. On the basis of a review of these studies, Maynard and Kuempel (2005) stated that surface area is the most relevant exposure metric for poorly soluble, low toxicity particles. The U.S. National Institute of Occupational Safety and Health ( NIOSH, 2005 ) has supported the conclusion, and in November 2005, proposed a recommended exposure limit (REL) of 0.1 mg/m 3 for ultrafine TiO 2 particles (primary particle size <100 nm), which is 15 times lower than that for fine TiO 2 particles (i.e., 1.5 mg/m 3 ). In a recently published paper by researchers from NIOSH ( Sager et al., 2008 ), it was stated that pulmonary response differ according to particle sizes and that the differences in the responses can be explained by the differences in particle surface area doses. In contrast, it has also been reported that the pulmonary toxicities on exposure to these types of particles did not depend upon particle size or surface area. Warheit et al. (2006) found no significant differences in the pulmonary effects of intratracheally instilled TiO 2 particles of different sizes, surface areas, and crystallinity in rats, although there were significant differences in particle surface area (i.e., up to 30 times). Further, following intratracheal instillation studies in rats exposed to TiO 2 and crystalline silica with different crystallinities, Warheit et al. (2007a,b) concluded that the surface chemistry is a considerably more important factor determining pulmonary toxicity than particle surface area. Regarding nano- and micron-sized crystalline silica, Kajiwara et al. (2007) compared pulmonary inflammation up to 6 months post-instillation between rats intratracheally instilled with normal Min-U-Sil 5 crystalline silica particles (geometrical mean of particle size = 1.8 μm) and those instilled with the supernatant (obtained by centrifugation) of these particles (geometrical mean of particle size = 0.74 μm). Their conclusion was that pulmonary inflammation is greater in the rats exposed to the micron-sized particles than those exposed to the supernatant. As mentioned earlier, the relationship between toxicity and particle size is still not clear. One of the reasons is considered to be differences in not only the size but also the crystallinity, surface chemistry, and purity of the test samples in most of the studies conducted so far. For example, ultrafine and fine TiO 2 particles had different crystalline structures in the studies conducted by Bermudez et al. (2002, 2004) and Sager et al. (2008) . For the ultrafine TiO 2 particles, both groups used 80% anatase and 20% rutile TiO 2 particles manufactured by Degussa; however, for the micron-sized TiO 2 particles, they used 100% rutile TiO 2 particles manufactured by either DuPont ( Bermudez et al., 2002 ) or Sigma–Aldrich ( Sager et al., 2008 ). Further, in some studies, the characterizations of the administered substances were not sufficient. Moreover, in most of the studies, only the 24-h post-instillation results were compared and assessed; only Warheit et al. (2006, 2007a, 2007b) and Kajiwara et al. (2007) assessed the results up to 3 months post-instillation. These differences make identification of the factors affecting toxicity very difficult. However, to assess the toxicity of nanoparticles and manage their risks, it is important to understand whether nanoparticles are more toxic than micron-sized particles. Therefore, in this study, two intratracheal instillation experiments with nano-TiO 2 particles of different primary sizes and agglomerations but the same manufacturer, manufacturing method, and crystalline structure (100% anatase) were conducted in rats to compare the biological responses in the lungs and other tissues of rats exposed to the different particle types. The results of these two experiments were then used to evaluate the relationships between pulmonary toxicity and particle size or agglomerations. 2 Materials and methods 2.1 Sample preparation In the first experiment (experiment 1), three different sizes of anatase TiO 2 particles (Ishihara Sangyo Kaisha, Ltd. Osaka, Japan) were used. The product names of these particles are ST-01, ST-21, and ST-41, corresponding to the primary particle sizes (grain sizes) of approximately 5, 23, and 154 nm. In this paper, these particle types are referred to as ultrafine (UF), superfine (SF), and fine (F) TiO 2 , respectively. To maintain the best dispersion state, 1–2 mg/mL disodium phosphate (DSP) was added as a dispersant to all the TiO 2 particle solutions, followed by agitation in an UAM015 agitating bead mill (Kotobuki Industries Co., Ltd., Tokyo, Japan) at 10–12 m/s for 2 h with 15-μm zirconium oxide (ZrO 2 ) beads. Subsequently, the supernatant was recovered by centrifugation at 8000 × g for 1 h (in the case of UF TiO 2 ), or the filtrate was recovered by filtration through a filter of 1-μm pore size (in the case of SF TiO 2 and F TiO 2 ). These solutions were intratracheally instilled after dilution with distilled water or concentration to a particle concentration of 5 mg/mL by using an evaporator. In the second experiment (experiment 2), only ST-01 particles (5-nm primary particle size) were used. By varying the preparation method, three different agglomeration states of TiO 2 particles in 2–13 mg/mL of DSP solution were obtained. In this paper, these particle types are referred to as UF1, UF2, and UF3 TiO 2 , in order of lower agglomeration. For preparing the UF1 TiO 2 particles, ST-01 particles were agitated using an UAM015 agitating bead mill at 12 m/s for 2 h with 15-μm ZrO 2 beads. Subsequently, the supernatant was recovered by centrifugation at 16,000 × g for 1 h. To prepare the UF2 TiO 2 particles, ST-01 particles were dispersed by sonication for 2 min, and then, the filtrate was recovered by filtration through filters of 1- and 0.1-μm pore sizes. To prepare the UF3 TiO 2 particles, ST-01 particles were agitated in an UAM015 agitating bead mill at 15 m/s for 1.5 h with 50-μm ZrO 2 beads, the filtrate was recovered by filtration through a filter of 1-μm pore size, and then the supernatant was recovered by centrifugation at 1000 × g for 1 h. The DSP concentrations were different in each TiO 2 sample solution, ranging from 2 mg/mL (UF1 TiO 2 ) to 13 mg/mL (UF3 TiO 2 ). In both experiments, 2 mg/mL DSP solution was used as the negative control (vehicle). Pulmonary effects induced by 13 mg/mL DSP solutions (same as that in the case of UF3 TiO 2 solutions) were examined by additional experiments: pulmonary responses due to the administration of the 13 mg/mL and 2 mg/mL DSP solutions were similar (data not shown). Further, in experiment 2, Min-U-Sil 5 crystalline silica particles (US Silica Co., Berkley Springs, WV) dispersed in 2 mg/mL of DSP solution was used as the positive control. Min-U-Sil 5 crystalline silica is known to produce continuous pulmonary inflammation in the lungs ( Warheit et al., 2007a; Kajiwara et al., 2007 ). 2.2 TiO 2 particle characterization Size distributions of each TiO 2 particle in DSP solution after sample preparation (i.e., secondary particle size distributions) were measured by the dynamic light scattering (DLS) method (Microtrac UPA150; Nikkiso Co., Ltd., Tokyo, Japan). Moreover, morphologies of the TiO 2 particles in the prepared solutions were observed by transmission electron microscopy (TEM). 2.3 Experimental animals In both experiments, 8-week-old male Crl: CD (SD) rats (Charles River Laboratories Japan, Inc., Yokohama, Japan) were used. Their mean body weight was in the range of 279–335 g at intratracheal instillation. 2.4 General experimental design In experiment 1, the rats were anesthetized with ether, and then, 1 mL/kg of sample solution was intratracheally instilled by using a 18-gauge indwelling needle, corresponding to 5 mg/kg of TiO 2 particle dose. Following the instillation, the viability and abnormal behavior of the rats were monitored once a day until dissection. The body weight of all the rats was measured before instillation and at 1, 3, 14, 21, and 28 days post-instillation. The weight of the lungs including that of the bronchi dissected at 3 days and 1 month post-instillation was measured. The bronchoalveolar lavage fluid (BALF) of the rats was examined for inflammatory biomarkers at 24 h and 1 week post-instillation. Histopathological evaluation of the lungs, liver, spleen, and cerebrum was also performed at 24 h, 3 days, 1 week, and 1 month post-instillation. In experiment 2, the rats were anesthetized with ether, and then, 1 mL/kg of sample solution was intratracheally instilled, corresponding to 5 mg/kg of TiO 2 or Min-U-Sil crystalline silica particle dose. Following the instillation, the viability and abnormal behavior of the rats were monitored once a day until dissection. The body and lung weights of all the rats were measured before instillation and at 1, 3, 7, 14, 21, 28, 35, 42, 49, 56, 63, 70, 77, 84, and 91 days post-instillation. The BALF and histopathological evaluation of the lungs, liver, spleen, cerebrum, and kidneys of the rats were performed for inflammatory markers at 24 h, 3 days, 1 week (7 days), 1 month (28 days) and 3 months (91 days) post-instillation. In both experiments, five rats per group were evaluated at each test point. 2.5 Pulmonary lavage The BALF of the rats was collected from the right lung. The rats were sacrificed after intraperitoneal injection of pentobarbital sodium (Nembutal injectable; Dainippon Sumitomo Pharma Co., Ltd., Tokyo, Japan). The bronchus of the left lung was clamped with forceps, and then, the right bronchus was cannulated. Subsequently, 3-mL heated saline ∼37 °C (Otsuka Pharmaceutical Factory, Inc., Tokushima, Japan) was instilled and aspirated, and the BALF was obtained. The supernatant obtained by centrifuging the BALF at 300 × g for 5 min was used for the chemokine and cytokine measurements. Thereafter, 2-mL saline solution was instilled and aspirated twice, and then these aspirates were centrifuged at 300 × g for 5 min after addition to the residues obtained by centrifugation of the BALF. The cell fraction was used to determine the cell counts in the BALF. 2.6 Pulmonary cell proliferation studies The cell fractions obtained by using the aforementioned method were suspended in saline, and then, the number of total cells, neutrophils, macrophages (monocytes), lymphocytes, and eosinophils were counted with a XT-2000iV automatic erythrocyte analyzer (Sysmex Corporation, Hyogo, Japan). 2.7 Chemokine and cytokine measurements Lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) concentrations in the supernatant obtained by centrifugation were measured with a TBA-200FR automatic biochemical analyzer (Toshiba Medical Systems Corporation, Tochigi, Japan). Interleukin (IL)-1α, IL-1β, IL-2, IL-4, IL-6, IL-10, IL-12, granulocyte monocyte colony stimulating factor (GM-CSF), interferon (IFN)-γ, and tumor necrosis factor (TNF)-α concentrations were measured by using a Rat Cytokine 10-Plex kit (Invitrogen Corporation, Tokyo, Japan) and Bio-Plex Suspension Array System (Bio-Rad Laboratories, Inc., Tokyo, Japan). 2.8 Histopathology studies The trachea, left lung, liver, spleen, cerebrum, and kidney (only in experiment 2) of all the rats were fixed with 10% (v/v) neutral phosphate-buffered formalin solution. Thin slices were prepared from paraffin blocks of all the preserved tissues and then stained with hematoxylin–eosin. The slices were observed through a light microscope. 2.9 Statistical analyses Statistical analyses of the body and lung weights and the cell numbers, biochemical parameters, and mRNA in the BALF were conducted. Statistical significance was determined by using multiple comparison tests between the control and TiO 2 -exposed groups. First, Bartlett's test was conducted. One-way layout analysis of variance was conducted when the variances were equal. Dunnet's multiple comparison tests were conducted when the differences between the groups were not significant. When the variances, as determined by the test of equal variance, were not equal, Kruskal–Wallis's tests were conducted. Steel's multiple comparison tests were conducted when the differences were significant. Statistical significances were judged at the 0.05 probability level. SAS System version 6.12 (SAS Institute Japan Ltd., Tokyo, Japan) was used for all the statistical analyses. 3 Results 3.1 TiO 2 particle characterization The mean secondary particle diameters of the UF, SF, and F TiO 2 particles were 19, 28, and 176 nm, respectively. The mean secondary particle diameters of the UF1, UF2, and UF3 TiO 2 particles were 18, 65, and 300 nm, respectively. The size distributions measured by DLS and the TEM images of each TiO 2 particle type are presented in Fig. 1 . The results of the characterization of these particles are summarized in Table 1 . In both experiments, X-ray fluorescence (XRF) analysis of all the TiO 2 suspensions confirmed that no residues of ZrO 2 particles were present. pH of the TiO 2 suspensions and the controls were in the range of 8.3–8.8. 3.2 Body and lung weights In both experiments, the body weights increased with increasing age. Statistically significant differences in body weight were not observed between any of the TiO 2 particle-exposed groups and the control group. In experiment 1, the lung weights were significantly greater in the UF and SF TiO 2 -exposed groups than in the control group at 3 days post-instillation, but there were no significant differences at 1 month post-instillation among any of the TiO 2 -exposed groups and the control group ( Fig. 2 a ). In experiment 2, the lung weights were significantly greater only at 1 month post-instillation in the UF1 TiO 2 -exposed group ( Fig. 3 a ). Further, lung weights were significantly greater at 24 h and 3 months post-instillation in the Min-U-Sil particle-exposed group. 3.3 BALF results 3.3.1 Pulmonary inflammation In experiment 1, significantly greater total cell numbers and percentages of neutrophils were observed in the UF and SF TiO 2 -exposed groups than in the control group at 24 h post-instillation ( Fig. 2 b and c). On the other hand, no significantly greater values of these pulmonary inflammatory parameters were observed in the F TiO 2 -exposed group at any time point. Consequently, greater pulmonary inflammatory responses were induced by the UF and SF TiO 2 particles than the F TiO 2 particles up to 1 week post-instillation. In experiment 2, significantly greater values of these parameters were observed in all the TiO 2 particle-exposed groups up to 1 week post-instillation, but no differences were observed between the control group and all the TiO 2 -exposed groups at 1 and 3 months post-instillation ( Fig. 3 b and c). On the other hand, the Min-U-Sil particle produced continuous inflammation; the inflammatory parameters significantly increased until 3 months post-instillation. 3.3.2 LDH and cytokines In experiment 1, significantly greater LDH levels were observed in the UF and SF TiO 2 -exposed groups than in the control group at 24 h post-instillation only ( Fig. 2 d). On the other hand, no significant increase in the LDH level was observed in the F TiO 2 -exposed group at any time point. Among the cytokines measured in this study, only the IL-6 concentration in the UF TiO 2 -exposed group at 24 h post-instillation was significantly increased (data not shown). The other cytokines were below the detection limit or did not have significantly high values in comparison with the control group. In experiment 2, significantly greater LDH levels were observed in the UF1 and UF3 TiO 2 -exposed groups only at 24 h post-instillation, and not in the UF2 TiO 2 -exposed group at any time point ( Fig. 3 d). Regarding to the cytokine measurements, significantly greater IL-1β and IL-6 levels were observed in the UF1 and UF3 TiO 2 -exposed groups only at 24 h post-instillation (data not shown). On the other hand, significantly greater LDH and these cytokine levels were observed in Min-U-Sil particle-exposed group at 24 h and 3 months post-instillation. 3.4 Histopathological evaluation In both experiments, histopathological changes were observed only in the lungs in all the groups. Therefore, only the histopathological evaluations of the lungs have been described in the following. In experiment 1, the grades of the pulmonary inflammatory responses differed among the TiO 2 particle-exposed groups up to 1 week post-instillation; there were no significant differences at 1 month post-instillation ( Table 2 ). At 1 week post-instillation ( Fig. 4 ), alveolar and interstitial macrophage infiltrations were observed in the UF TiO 2 -exposed group. Inflammatory cell infiltration and alveolar epithelium hypertrophy were also observed in this group. In the SF TiO 2 -exposed group, alveolar macrophage infiltration and inflammatory cell infiltration were observed; but at a lower grade than those in the UF TiO 2 particle-exposed group. In the F TiO 2 particle-exposed group, alveolar macrophage and inflammatory cell infiltrations were considerably milder than in the UF and SF TiO 2 -exposed groups. At 1 month post-instillation ( Fig. 5 ), the inflammatory responses remarkably recovered, and only minimal alveolar macrophage infiltration was observed in all the TiO 2 particle-exposed groups. Further, the severity of the findings was comparable among the TiO 2 particle-exposed groups. In experiment 2, there were no significant differences in the grades of the inflammatory responses among the TiO 2 particle-exposed groups at any time point ( Table 3 ). As in experiment 1, alveolar macrophage and inflammatory cell infiltrations recovered very quickly, and only minimal macrophage infiltration was observed in all the TiO 2 particle-exposed groups at 1 month post-instillation ( Fig. 6 ). In the Min-U-Sil particle-exposed group, short-term inflammatory responses were weak: slight-to-mild inflammatory cell infiltrations were observed until 1 month post-instillation. However, the inflammatory responses became much stronger at 3 months post-instillation ( Fig. 7 ). Consequently, Min-U-Sil particle produced continuous inflammation with a 5 mg/kg dose of intratracheal instillation, which was the significant difference in comparison with the same doses of the TiO 2 particle instillation. The results of the histopathological evaluations were consistent with the results of the BALF cell and LDH measurements. 4 Discussion In this study, two intratracheal instillation experiments with nano-TiO 2 particles of different sizes and agglomerations were conducted in rats, and the biological responses in the lungs and other tissues were compared among the TiO 2 particle-exposed groups at each post-instillation time point. In experiment 1, the inflammatory biomarkers and tissue inflammatory responses to the TiO 2 particles were in the order UF TiO 2 > SF TiO 2 > F TiO 2 until 1 week post-instillation. Therefore, in the short term, smaller TiO 2 particles induced greater inflammatory responses in the lungs at the same mass dose. However, at 1 month post-instillation, the inflammatory responses remarkably recovered in all the TiO 2 particle-exposed groups, and no significant differences in the pulmonary inflammation were observed among the groups. Differences in pulmonary inflammation were observed only in the short-term (≤1 week post-exposure). In experiment 2, the inflammatory biomarkers and tissue inflammatory responses were different only at 24 h post-instillation; and there were no significant differences among the TiO 2 particle-exposed groups at any other time point. At 1 month post-instillation, the inflammatory responses recovered in all the TiO 2 particle-exposed groups and no significant differences were observed. Therefore, there is no clear relationship between pulmonary inflammation and particle agglomeration. On the other hand, the pulmonary inflammatory responses in the Min-U-Sil particle-exposed group were totally different from those of the TiO 2 particle-exposed groups: continuous pulmonary inflammation was observed for at least 3 months post-instillation. In both experiments, inflammatory responses were observed only in the lungs, and not in the liver, spleen, cerebrum, and kidney in all the groups. In summary, the pulmonary inflammatory responses in the short-term differed among the groups with different primary particle sizes. Until 1 week post-instillation, the differences were dependent on the primary sizes of the TiO 2 particles (i.e., smaller TiO 2 particles induced greater inflammation with the same mass dose). The differences may be due to the differences in particle surface area or particle number. The surface area dose was 1.58, 0.33, and 0.05 m 2 /kg in the UF, SF, and F TiO 2 particle-exposed groups, respectively. The difference in the surface area dose was more than 30 times between the UF and F TiO 2 particle-exposed groups. With regard to the long-term effects (≥1 month post-instillation), pulmonary inflammation remarkably recovered in all the TiO 2 particle-exposed groups, with no differences between the groups in particle sizes. On the other hand, there was no clear relationship in pulmonary inflammation among the rats instilled with TiO 2 particles of the same primary size but different particle agglomerations. Oberdörster et al. (1992, 1994) reported that rats intratracheally instilled with or inhaling smaller (20 nm) TiO 2 particles had greater inflammatory responses than those exposed to larger (250 nm) TiO 2 particles. Further, when the doses were expressed in terms of particle surface area, the responses of ultrafine and fine TiO 2 particles fell on the same dose–response curve ( Oberdörster, 2000; Oberdörster et al., 2005; Donaldson et al., 2001 ). They therefore concluded that the greater inflammatory responses induced by the ultrafine TiO 2 particles were due to the larger total surface area of these particles. Brown et al. (2000, 2001) and Duffin et al. (2007) also concluded that smaller particles produce greater inflammatory responses. However, this conclusion was derived from the 24 h post-instillation results only; the experimental results after 1 week post-instillation were not analyzed. In a study by Sager et al. (2008) , differences in pulmonary inflammation were observed between the groups of rats intratracheally instilled with two different sizes of TiO 2 particles until 42 days post-instillation. The authors concluded that these differences can be explained by the differences in the surface area dose of the instilled TiO 2 particles. Further, Bermudez et al. (2002, 2004) arrived at the same conclusion following a 13-week inhalation study in rats. However, the ultrafine and fine TiO 2 particles used in both studies had different crystalline structures. The researchers used 80% anatase and 20% rutile TiO 2 particles manufactured by Degussa as the ultrafine TiO 2 particles; however, 100% rutile TiO 2 particles manufactured by either DuPont ( Bermudez et al., 2002 ) or Sigma–Aldrich ( Sager et al., 2008 ) were used as the micron-sized TiO 2 particles. In the present study, the pulmonary inflammatory responses in the groups of rats instilled with different sizes and agglomerations of TiO 2 particles but by the same manufacturer, manufacturing method, and crystalline structure differed only in the short-term post-instillation. Therefore, different evaluations can be derived from the results obtained until 1 week post-instillation and those after 1 month post-instillation. When conducting a hazard assessment for humans by extrapolating the study results with experimental animals, it is important to evaluate not only the short-term effects such as transient inflammation, but also long-term effects such as persistent inflammation and fibrosis. Further, pulmonary inflammatory responses at 24 h post-instillation reflect the effects of the bolus exposure and instillation of the liquid into the lungs. Therefore, the 24 h post-instillation result does not fully express the toxicity of the instilled particles. For example, significant increases in the pulmonary inflammatory biomarkers, such as the numbers of neutrophils and LDH levels in BALF, were observed in phosphate-buffered saline (PBS) solution-exposed rats ( Warheit et al., 2006, 2007a,b ) and saline exposed rats ( Bergmann et al., 2000 ) at 24 h post-instillation. Judging from the facts, a toxicity evaluation based only on the results obtained at 24 h post-instillation could be misleading. In conclusion, the results of the present study indicate that both short- and long-term responses should be evaluated when conducting hazard assessments of nanoparticles according to the results of intratracheal instillation studies. 9wxF6y7g.title: Protein adsorption of ultrafine metal oxide and its influence on cytotoxicity toward cultured cells.
9wxF6y7g.abstract: Many investigations about the cellular response by metal oxide nanoparticles in vitro have been reported. However, the influence of the adsorption ability of metal oxide nanoparticles toward cells is unknown. The aim of this study is to understand the influence of adsorption by metal oxide nanoparticles on the cell viability in vitro. The adsorption abilities of six kinds of metal oxide nanoparticles, namely, NiO, ZnO, TiO2, CeO2, SiO2, and Fe2O3, to Dulbecco's modified Eagle's medium supplemented with a 10% fetal bovine serum (DMEM-FBS) component such as serum proteins and Ca2) were estimated. All of the metal oxide nanoparticles adsorbed proteins and Ca2+ in the DMEM-FBS; in particular, TiO2, CeO2, and ZnO showed strong adsorption abilities. Furthermore, the influence of the depletion of medium components by adsorption to metal oxide nanoparticles on cell viability and proliferation was examined. The particles were removed from the dispersion by centrifugation, and the supernatant was applied to the cells. Both the cell viability and the proliferation of human keratinocyte HaCaT cells and human lung carcinoma A549 cells were affected by the supernatant. In particular, cell proliferation was strongly inhibited by the supernatant of TiO2 and CeO2 dispersions. The supernatant showed depletion of serum proteins and Ca2+ by adsorption to metal oxide nanoparticles. When the adsorption effect was blocked by the pretreatment of particles with FBS, the inhibitory effect was lost. However, in NiO and ZnO, which showed ion release, a decrease of inhibitory effect by pretreatment was not shown. Furthermore, the association of the primary particle size and adsorption ability was examined in TiO2. The adsorption ability of TiO2 depended on the primary particle size. The TiO2 nanoparticles were size dependently absorbed with proteins and Ca2+, thereby inducing cytotoxicity. In conclusion, the adsorption ability of metal oxide nanoparticles is an important factor for the estimation of cytotoxicity in vitro for low-toxicity materials.

wJXF2jzD.title: Preparing samples for fullerene C60 hazard tests: Stable dispersion of fullerene crystals in water using a bead mill
wJXF2jzD.abstract: A dispersion method using a bead mill was developed for preparing suspensions used in hazard testing of nanosize fullerenes. Fullerene crystals (C 60 ) of several μm to 100 μm in size were wet ground using a bead mill and dispersed in pure water containing Tween 80 as a dispersant. The particle size, dispersing condition, crystallization and fullerene oxide in the suspension prepared by bead milling were evaluated. As a result, the conditions of bead milling where the sizes of fullerene crystals were reduced to 100 nm or less were found, which made it possible to prepare a fullerene aqueous dispersion system using Tween 80. Furthermore, by centrifugation, it became possible to prepare fullerene suspensions in which the particle size of the majority of the suspended particles was 100 nm or less. The prepared suspensions remained stable for almost two months. Controlling milling conditions and milling time made it possible to achieve dispersion while maintaining the crystallized state of the fullerenes, and operating in anaerobic conditions under shade effectively suppressed the production of oxidized fullerenes. The fullerene suspensions prepared by bead milling and centrifugation were suitable for endotracheal administration tests and inhalation tests using rats. Keywords Bead milling Fullerene suspension Tween 80 Dispersion Hazard test 1 Introduction Because of the highly unique characteristics of fullerene C 60 , research and development is being conducted for a wide variety of industrial uses, from biomedical technology and cosmetics to electronic devices and optical materials [1–3] . On the other hand, research has also been widely conducted on its biological effects using fish and rats [4,5] . Initially, interest in their medical applications (e.g. DDS) generated a great deal of research into reactions within organisms that had been injected with fullerenes, but as they become more widely used as industrial products, more research is being conducted on how exposure through the medium of the environment affects human health and organisms [6,7] . However, there are few studies of their harmful effects in which particle size, the most important characteristic of the particles, was precisely evaluated or controlled in the test samples. In order to properly assess the biological effects of nanoparticles, including fullerenes, the characteristics of the hazard test samples, including particle size, must be sufficiently controlled and evaluated. This study aims to develop a method for preparing test samples where the distribution of particle size is controlled and evaluated in order to assess the effect on organisms and human health from exposure to fullerenes through the environment. When evaluating the effect of all nanoparticles—not just fullerenes—on human health, the inhalation pathway is the most important of all exposure pathways, so it is essential to assess the affect of exposure through inhalation. Accordingly, in this study a method is developed for preparing fullerene aqueous dispersion samples to be used in in vivo hazard tests of inhalation pathways in rodents, particularly in endotracheal administration tests and inhalation tests. It is assumed that the wet nanoparticle production method will be used in inhalation tests, where aqueous suspensions of nanoparticles are converted into an aerosol. Some methods of dispersing fullerenes in water involve dissolving them first with aromatic solvents like toluene, adding water, and then distilling the solvent [8,9] , or using the comparatively low-toxicity tetrahydrofuran THF as a solvent [10] , but studies have pointed to the effect of residual solvents and changes in the particles’ electric charge that occur when organic solvents are used. Moreover, a method [11,12] is being studied that does not use an organic solvent, dispersing C 60 in water by subsuming it inside a cyclodextrin, but this method has not reached the stage of preparing nano-level suspensions. Recently, Deguchi et al. have reported a convenient fullerene aqueous dispersion method using hand grinding in a mortar [13] , and they suggest that this method enables dispersion down to the nano-level. This method is extremely attractive, but they report a 5% mass standard for recovery of nanoparticles in a filtrate using a 100 nm filter. When tests for inhalation exposure are taken into consideration, the low yield of nanosize particles is problematic. Recently, however, as demand increases for industrial uses of suspensions of nanosized particles, several types of liquid phase dispersion have been attempted: high-pressure dispersion using shock waves (cavitation) [14] ; crashing particles by their collision together at high speeds [15] ; and tensile rupture in high-velocity and high-shear fields [16] . Among these various attempts, a method using small beads less than 100 μm in diameter, one type of wet milling/dispersion method is drawing attention [17,18] . It is said that the bead mill method using small beads makes it possible to disperse nanoparticle agglomerates virtually to the primary particle, and it also makes it possible to ensure high throughput. This study examines a method of suspending fullerenes in water using a bead mill in order to prepare test samples for in vivo hazard tests of nanoscale fullerene particles. It also investigates a method of regulating the particle size in suspensions to be used as test samples. 2 Experimental methods 2.1 Requisites for prepared suspension When conducting in vivo hazard tests in rodents using C 60 aqueous suspensions, it was determined that test samples had to meet the following requisites: the mass median diameter of suspended particle sizes had to be less than 100 nm; and in endotracheal administration tests, the concentration of C 60 particles had to be 0.5 mg/mL, which enables the administration of 0.5 mg per 1 kg of rodent body weight. Suspensions prepared this way can also be used in inhalation exposure tests, where the suspension is atomized as an aerosol. When preparing suspensions for testing purposes, the use of solvents should be avoided if possible, but since fullerenes are hydrophobic, it is difficult to disperse them in water without using a solvent. Therefore, this study used a surfactant, which has been approved in connection with food safety and hygiene [19] , and has also been used in previous inhalation tests. 2.2 Preparation of sample and dispersion medium The C 60 fullerene used as a raw material was crystalline Nanom Purple TR , purchased from Frontier Carbon Co. (Kitakyushu, Japan). It is produced by the combustion method, and further purified by sublimation. An SEM image is given in Fig. 1 . Particles in the raw material were large in size (100 μm or more). The pure water used in dispersion, deoxidized through Argon replacement, was obtained by the following method. Ultrapure water that was ion exchanged with MillQ (Millipore, Billerica, US) was filtrated with an endotoxin removal filter (Bio-pack, Millipore). Furthermore, to control the oxidation of the fullerenes, the filtrated ultrapure water was boiled in a 1 L conical flask for approximately 5–10 min. After confirming that bubbles on the walls of the flask had vanished, argon gas was bubbled while rapidly cooling with ice water, and bubbling was suspended after confirming that the concentration of dissolved oxygen in the water measured by SevenGo pro (Mettler Toledo, Schwerzenbach, Switzerland) was 0.01 mg/L or less. In order to suspend hydrophobic fullerenes in water, the nonionic surfactant Tween 80 (Polyoxyethylene (20) sorbitan monooleate, Wako Pure Chemical Industries, Ltd., Osaka, Japan) was used as a dispersant. Tween 80 was selected because it was used in endotracheal administration tests in rats with no reported secondary effects, in a concentration of 1%, as a dispersion medium in multilayer carbon nanotubes ground with a ball mill [20] , and also because the stability of fullerenes in Tween 80 aqueous solutions had been studied [21] . In a globe box that had been nitrogen substituted so the oxygen concentration was less than 0.1%, Tween 80 was added to the deoxidized water mentioned above, and a dispersion medium adjusted for the designated concentration of dispersant was used in the following dispersion method. 2.3 Dispersion method The bead mill (UAM-15, Kotobuki Industries Co., Ltd., Kure, Japan) shown in Fig. 2 was used for wet dispersion of C 60 . Since the particles in the raw material were large in size (100 μm or more) as indicated in Fig. 1 , preliminary grinding was performed inside a nitrogen-substituted globe box prior to bead mill dispersion. For 30 min, the designated amount of the raw material, to which trace amounts of the dispersion medium had been added, was ground and kneaded in an agate mortar. The suspension for use in bead mill dispersion was obtained by adding a Tween 80 aqueous solution to the raw material and adjusting the concentration of C 60 to 0.1–5 mg/mL. Five hundred millilitres of the raw material suspension were put inside a bead mill, which had been purged of nitrogen in advance, and wet dispersed under a nitrogen current (4–5 mL/min) for the designated period of time. Approximately 400 g of zirconia beads (Nikkato Co., Osaka, Japan) with diameter D B of 15–50 μm were used for the beads, which filled approximately 63% of the mill capacity. The mill was operated with the circumferential velocity v of the stirring blade at 8–15 m/s and the flow rate of the suspension at 10 L/h. Both grinding in the globe box and bead mill dispersion were carried out in shade in order to suppress fullerene oxidation. Two additional samples were also prepared for comparison: a sample ground by hand in a mortar, and a dispersion sample produced by ultrasonication. The sample ground by hand in a mortar was prepared according to the method of Deguchi et al. [10,13] . First, 10 mg of the raw material C 60 particles was put into an agate mortar, and after adding the dispersion medium described above in Section 2.2 , the sample was ground by hand for 2 min. The fullerenes that adhered to the agate pestle were removed with a spatula and returned to the mortar, and the grinding procedure was repeated ten times. The obtained ground material was suspended in a designated amount of the dispersion medium and churned in a stirrer for 24 h. A dispersion sample produced by ultrasonication was prepared using an ultrasonic homogenizer with maximum output of 50 W (Model 250, Branson Ultrasonics Co., Danbury, USA) to disperse the slurry that was hand ground by the method described above. 2.4 Adjusting particle size in a suspension by centrifugation The objective of this study is the preparation of an aqueous solution in which the size of the majority of fullerene particles is kept under 100 nm. After the preparation by bead milling, the suspension was centrifugated at a given centrifugal intensity (=ratio of centrifugal acceleration to gravitational one) for 1 h (MX-300, TOMY Seiko Co., Ltd., Tokyo, Japan). 2.5 Characterization Particle sizes were measured using laser diffraction (Helos, Sympatec GmbH, Clausthal-Zellerfeld, Germany) and dynamic light scattering (DLS; UPA 150, Microtrac Inc., Montgomeryville, USA), and zeta potential was measured with Zetasizer Nano (Malvern Instrument Ltd., Worcestershire, UK). Dispersion states, grain shapes, and crystallization states were observed using transmission electron microscopy (TEM; JEOL Ltd., Tokyo, Japan), high-resolution TEM (EM922, Carl Zeiss NTS, Oberkochen, Germany), and scanning electron microscopy (SEM; JSM-5410, JEOL Ltd., Tokyo, Japan). Furthermore, impurities were measured using X-ray fluorescence analysis (XRF; JSX-3201, JEOL Ltd., Tokyo, Japan) and an energy dispersive X-ray spectrometer (EDS; JSM-5410, JEOL Ltd., Tokyo, Japan). The concentration of fullerenes within the prepared suspension was measured by assessing the absorbance of visible–UV light, primarily at wavelengths of 340 nm (UV-2550, Shimadzu, Kyoto, Japan). Furthermore, the production of oxidized fullerenes was measured using high performance liquid chromatography (HPLC; Agilent 1100, Agilent Technologies, USA) after fullerenes in the suspension were dissolved with toluene. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Assessing particle concentration Fig. 3 shows the absorbance spectra within the visible–UV range of the C 60 suspension wet ground by bead mill in a Tween 80 1 mg/mL aqueous solution (without ultracentrifugation) as well as of the Tween 80 1 mg/mL aqueous solution used as a dispersant. While absorbance was observed at wavelengths of 234 nm in the Tween 80 aqueous solution, two strong absorbance peaks dominated the spectrum of C 60 suspension, i.e., bands at 261 nm and 340 nm. Both arise from electronic transitions of C 60 and shifted to more red than C 60 molecules [22–24] . Given that absolutely no absorbance at wavelengths of 340 nm was observed in the Tween 80 aqueous solution, measuring the degree of absorbance at 340 nm is believed to enable assessment of C 60 concentration within the suspension. Since the recovered suspension contained the particle having sizes of relatively wide range or over 100 nm in size, the particle size should be adjusted into less than 100 nm by the centrifugation, as described in Section 3.4 . In this work, the concentration of C 60 in the supernatant obtained by ultracentrifugation of the suspension should be measured. The relationship between the absorbance at 340 nm and the concentration of C 60 particles within the supernatant of centrifuged suspension, estimated by drying the suspension and weighing the mass of C 60 particles, is given in Fig. 4 (a). As the graph indicates, a clear proportional relationship was obtained, and it is possible to assess the concentration of C 60 particles within the suspension by measuring the degree of absorbance at 340 nm. Since there was also very good agreement between HPLC liquid chromatography assessment and UV–Vis one of the C 60 toluene solution as shown in Fig. 4 (b), absorbance at 340 nm was used to assess the C 60 particle concentration in this study. 3.2 Dispersion by mortar and ultrasonication Fig. 5 shows the particle size distributions Q 3 ( x ) based on mass for fullerenes in the sample treated to hand grinding in a mortar and in a sample that was further dispersed by ultrasonication, along with SEM photographs. The concentrations of C 60 and Tween 80 were adjusted at 0.1 mg/mL. As the SEM photographs demonstrate, the crushed particles were several μm in size. Furthermore, it was observed that these particles formed agglomerates of several tens of μm. Since the particle sizes go beyond the size range measured by DLS, the particle size distributions shown in Fig. 5 were measured using laser diffraction. No significant variance was observed between the particle size distributions of the particles in the suspension produced by hand grinding and the suspension produced by ultrasonication. The particles produced contained 20 wt% of fine particles smaller than 1 μm, but the majority were micron-sized; it was difficult to grind C 60 crystals to nanosizes using these methods. Deguchi et al. indicated the possibility of using hand grinding in mortars to disperse sub-micron fine particles in an SDS (sodium dodecyl sulfate) aqueous solution [13] , but miniaturization below 100 nm was not achieved in this experiment. It is thought that dispersion by more powerful mechanical processing is required, but as discussed below, there is concern that the crystalline structure of fullerenes may be destroyed by powerful mechanical processing. 3.3 Aqueous dispersion of fullerenes using a bead mill 3.3.1 Oxidation of fullerenes Oxidized fullerenes are known to be produced through exposure to light within the solvent or through oscillating mill grinding in an oxygen atmosphere [25,26] , and it is expected that oxidized fullerenes will be produced during bead mill dispersion as well, depending on the conditions. Fig. 6 shows a comparison between the production of oxidized fullerenes when preparation of the dispersion medium and bead milling were performed in air without shading versus treatment in a shaded, anaerobic environment. The suspensions with a C 60 concentration of 1.5 mg/mL in Tween 80 aqueous solution of 1.0 mg/mL were prepared by bead milling using beads with a diameter D B = 50 μm stirred by a blade rotating at a speed of 15 m/s. The mass content of C 60 and C 60 –O was sought from the HPLC output. When treated in air and under room lights, the C 60 –O content was 3–4% after 30 min of dispersion and 7% after 60 min; by contrast, the C 60 –O content was 0.7–0.8% after 30 min of grinding in anaerobic, shaded conditions. Deoxidizing the dispersion medium, water, along with preliminary hand grinding and bead milling under anaerobic, shaded conditions were effective in controlling the production of oxidized fullerenes, enabling the C 60 –O content to be kept below 1% and both were used for hazard tests. 3.3.2 Particle size of fullerenes ground in bead mills Fig. 7 shows the relationship between dispersing time t D and particle size distribution of C 60 along with photographs of the suspension. Fullerenes at a concentration of 0.1 mg/mL were ground in Tween 80 aqueous solution of 1.0 mg/mL. The bead mill was operated using beads with a diameter D B = 50 μm stirred by blades rotating at a speed of 10 m/s. In this figure, the size of particles in the raw material ( t D = 0) that was hand ground is indicated in the range of 0.5 μm to several μm, but this is because the measurement limitations of DLS meant that particles larger than several μm were not measured. Compared to the state of the suspensions in the photograph, it is clear that sedimentary particles larger than 10 μm exist. With a dispersing time of 45–60 min, the finest distribution of particle sizes was obtained, with a mass median diameter x 50,3 of 50 nm and a mass fraction of over 80% for particles less than 100 nm in size. Furthermore, as the photographs illustrate, the suspension became a transparent, amber liquid after approximately 30 min, and it became a transparent suspension with the darkest color at 45–60 min. The particle mass concentration of the suspension milled for 60 min decreased to 70–80% of the initial concentration. It is believed that the greatest production of fine particles occurred between 45 and 60 min. Subsequently, a drop in concentration was observed, and it had decreased to less than 10% of prepared concentration at 120 min. Based on these observations, it became clear that bead milling is effective for grinding fullerenes to sizes smaller than 100 nm. It was also confirmed that Tween 80 is effective in aqueous dispersion of fullerenes. Fig. 8 shows the relationship between mass median diameter x 50,3 and dispersing time t D (a). Using D B = 50 μm beads, which have a great deal of kinetic energy, enabled dispersion of up to 50 nm in 45–60 min. In this case, however, particle size increased if dispersing time continued any longer, and as indicated in Fig. 7 , particle concentration dropped and the suspension lost its color, becoming opaque at 120 min. It is presumed that the causes of the increase in particle size and the drop in particle concentration after 60 min were that size reduction activated the surface of the C 60 and groups of particles agglomerated, adhering to the beads and the walls of the mill. After the bead milling, the color of the beads was clearly changed into brown, and the color change was remarkable when the milling went well. This means that the fullerene particles ground to finer adhered to the beads for long bead mill operation. Furthermore, the long milling activated the surface of ground particles and the C 60 particles agglomerated. Re-agglomeration of nanoparticles has also been observed in wet dispersion of titania nanoparticles in a bead mill [18] , but further study is required to explain the causes of the phenomenon and ways to suppress it. Conversely, when mechanical conditions were weakened by the use of beads of 30 μm or 15 μm in diameter, particles in the suspension became larger and particles of 300 nm in size were obtained after 1 h of dispersion. The particle size was slightly reduced when dispersing time was increased, with particle sizes of about 200 nm achieved at 2 h, but large changes were not observed. 3.3.3 Crystallization of particles produced Fig. 8 shows a high-resolution TEM image of particles treated to 120 min of dispersion. At D B = 15 μm and stirring speed v = 8 m/s (b), a lattice pattern was observed in the TEM image, and crystallization was maintained. On the other hand, decrystallization occurred at D B = 50 μm, v = 10 m/s (c). These results suggest that dispersion under mild mechanical conditions, or dispersion for short periods, is required in order to maintain the crystalline structure of fullerenes. 3.4 Preparing a suspension by centrifugation 3.4.1 Particle size The objective of this study is the preparation of solution for in vivo hazard tests of nanoscale fullerene particles. And as written in 2.1, a comparatively high concentration of C 60 particles (about 0.5 mg/mL) has to be secured in endotracheal administration tests. As increase the particle concentration, milling efficiency decrease and size of milled particle increase. Taking the preceding discussion into consideration, it was discovered that dispersion for a short period under relatively strong dispersion conditions was desirable in order to obtain the desired sample, where the fullerenes’ crystalline structure is kept intact. Thus, D B = 50 μm, v = 15 m/s, and 30 min were employed as milling conditions, and a suspension with a C 60 concentration of 1.5 mg/mL (Tween 80 concentration = 1.0 mg/mL) was prepared. After the milling, the prepared suspension was centrifugated to adjust the particle size and the concentration. Fig. 9 shows the particle distribution in the supernatant centrifuged at centrifugal intensities (=ratio of centrifugal acceleration to gravitational one) of 4000, 8000, and 16,000 for 1 h. The x 50,3 of fullerenes in the suspension prior to centrifugation was about 100 nm, but as centrifugal intensities were increased, the x 50,3 of the recovered supernatant became 60 nm, 32 nm, and 17 nm, and the 90% diameter of the mass standard decreased, from 170 nm to 83 nm to 55 nm. These results revealed that it is possible to prepare a C 60 aqueous dispersion system with the majority of fullerene particles at less than 100 nm by regulating the conditions of centrifugation. Also, relative to the particle concentration of the suspension introduced into the bead mill, the particle mass concentrations for the supernatants recovered through this method of centrifugation were 40–42% (4000), 25–30% (8000), and 14–15% (16,000), respectively. Impurities in those supernatants were measured using XRF and EDS. The XRF spectrum of the solid obtained by drying the supernatant centrifuged at a centrifugal intensity of 8000 (solid line) is shown in Fig. 10 and the spectrum obtained from the water containing Fe of 100 ppm as a tracer is shown in the figure (broken line). The difference in the both spectra was not clear excluding fluorescent X-ray of Fe and the intensity of fluorescent X-ray for Zr which was expected as contaminants arising from the abrasion of beads, stirring blades, and inner wall of mill was the same level of the noise. No impurities from the bead milling believed to result from the bead mill were detected. 3.4.2 Stability The stability of the supernatant recovered by centrifugation was examined. The C 60 suspension was initially prepared by bead milling at a concentration of 1.5 mg/mL in 1.0 mg/mL Tween 80 aqueous solution. The mill was operated at a blade rotational speed of 15 m/s using D B = 50 μm beads. After 30 min milling, the suspension was centrifugated at centrifugal intensity of 8000. The supernatant was split into vials of 10 mL, and those vials were left sitting in a refrigerator for a certain period. The suspensions of 2 mL were sampled from different vials to measure the concentration and the size distribution of C 60 . Fig. 11 shows the stability of concentration for C 60 particles in the supernatant (a). The concentrations of C 60 by the centrifugation were 0.48 mg/mL and the suspension was diluted into 0.24 mg/mL. Their photographs are shown in Fig. 11 ((b): 0.48 mg/mL; (c): 0.24 mg/mL). The concentrations of the suspensions obtained by this method were constant for almost two months, regardless of particle concentration. Fig. 12 shows the stability of particle size distribution for C 60 particles in the supernatant. As the diagrams indicate, there is little variation in size distribution of the suspension for almost two months. The suspensions maintained a highly stable dispersion state. The relationship between zeta potential of C 60 particles in the suspension and concentration of dispersant is shown in Fig. 13 . The concentrations of C 60 were ranging from 0.2 mg/mL to 0.3 mg/mL. Tween 80 is nonionic, so fullerenes in a Tween 80 aqueous solution (pH 7.0) indicate a zeta potential of approximately −30 mV for lower dispersant concentration. This value is quite close to values obtained for fullerenes in other aqueous solutions [27] , and it gives the surface electric charge of C 60 particle. On the other hand, the zeta potential decreased at the Tween 80 concentration of 1 mg/mL. It seemed that the coverage of Tween 80 molecules on the C 60 particle surface increased and the electric charge of C 60 decreased, as increase of the dispersant concentration. It is believed that the stability of C 60 in Tween 80 aqueous solution as shown in Figs. 11–13 was maintained by not only the surface electrical interaction, but the repulsion of the dispersant molecule structure. 3.4.3 Crystalline structure Fig. 14 shows high-resolution TEM observation results for C 60 particles in the supernatant recovered by centrifugation of C 60 suspension milled at blade rotational speed of 15 m/s using D B = 50 μm bead for 30 min. From those results, it was observed that the primary particles in suspensions regulated by centrifugation were about 20–50 nm in size, and that these particles agglomerate, forming secondary particles about 50–100 nm in size. However, it is unclear whether the secondary particles observed by TEM are particles in a suspended state, or whether they were formed during the production of samples for TEM observation. Furthermore, given that crystalline lattices could be clearly observed, as the photographs demonstrate, it was possible to confirm that these were particles that maintained the crystalline state of C 60 . In addition, diffraction patterns were also observed using selected-area electron diffraction and the pattern is shown in Fig. 15 [28] . Based on these results, it was discovered that suspensions of C 60 smaller than 100 nm that maintain their face-centered cubic (fcc) crystalline structure having a lattice constant of 1.42 nm could be prepared by short-term bead mill dispersion, even under strong dispersion conditions. Fullerene suspensions prepared under these conditions are suitable for endotracheal administration tests and inhalation tests using rats [29,30] . 4 Conclusion In order to establish a method of preparing aqueous fullerene solutions suitable for use in hazard tests of nanosize fullerenes, a mechanical dispersion method using a bead mill was examined. As a result, the following conclusions were drawn: (1) It was discovered that fullerene crystals larger than several μm in size can be wet dispersed to sizes below 100 nm using a bead mill with very small beads, and that it is possible to prepare aqueous C 60 solutions using Tween 80 as a dispersant. Furthermore, with centrifugation it was possible to regulate the size of most of the suspended particles below 100 nm, and suspensions prepared by that method were stable for 2 weeks or more. (2) By appropriately configuring the conditions for bead mill dispersion (stirring speed, bead size, dispersing time), it is possible to preserve the crystalline structure of C 60 . (3) By conducting the dispersion process, including preparation of the dispersant medium, in anaerobic, shaded conditions, it is possible to suppress the production of oxidized fullerenes. (4) Fullerene suspensions prepared by bead milling and centrifugation are suitable for endotracheal administration tests and inhalation tests using rats. Gqe0Mryf.title: Cellular responses by stable and uniform ultrafine titanium dioxide particles in culture-medium dispersions when secondary particle size was 100nm or less
Gqe0Mryf.abstract: Even though there have been some investigations into cellular responses induced by ultrafine titanium dioxide (TiO 2 ) in vitro , the relationship between cellular responses and secondary particle size is still not clear. In this study, a stable and uniform TiO 2 -cell culture-medium dispersion was prepared, and cellular responses prompted by “ultrafine secondary particles” were examined. The TiO 2 –DMEM–FBS dispersion included secondary particles in which the secondary particle size was 100 nm or less. In the present study, a “secondary particle” was defined as a complex aggregate of TiO 2 primary particles, proteins from FBS and other medium components. Secondary particle size did not influence the cell viability. The TiO 2 –DMEM–FBS dispersion introduced to the human keratinocyte HaCaT cells caused weak intracellular oxidative stress and apoptosis. The cellular influence of ultrafine TiO 2 in vitro is caused by the following mechanisms: (1) Secondary particles are formed. Ultrafine TiO 2 particles dispersed in medium immediately form secondary particles with proteins and salts. (2) “Ultrafine” secondary particles are taken up by the cells. The secondary particles reach the cells by diffusion and/or sedimentation and are taken up by the cells, through endocytosis. (3) Intracellular reactive oxygen species (ROS) level increases. Internalized secondary particles induce an increase in intracellular reactive oxygen species levels, although the secondary particles do not break up in the cell. In the case of ultrafine TiO 2 , the increase of the intracellular ROS level was minimal. Moreover, the antioxidation system of cells such as glutathione was working. (4) Apoptotic cell death is induced. An accumulation of oxidative stress activates the apoptotic pathway (such as the caspase-3) and subsequently induces apoptotic cell death. After 24 h of exposure to TiO 2 , the percentage of apoptotic cells was only 6–7%. As a result, although the ultrafine TiO 2 particles induce some cellular responses, these cellular responses to ultrafine TiO 2 are weaker than those of other cytotoxic ultrafine metal oxide particles, such as nickel oxide. Keywords Titanium dioxide Nanoparticle Oxidative stress Apoptosis Dynamic light scattering

Wzk4AsWn.title: Development and evaluation of an aerosol generation and supplying system for inhalation experiments of manufactured nanoparticles.
Wzk4AsWn.abstract: Risk assessment of nanoparticles by inhalation experiments is of great importance since inhalation is considered the most significant route of exposure to nanoparticles suspended in air. However, there have been few inhalation experiments using manufactured nanoparticles, mainly because of the difficulty in stably dispersing the nanoparticles in air for a long period of time. In this study, we report for the first time the development of a rational system for stably and continuously dispersing and supplying manufactured nanoparticles for inhalation experiments. The system was developed using a spray-drying technique, in which a nebulizer was used to atomize nickel oxide (NiO) and fullerene (C60) nanoparticle suspensions, and the resulting droplets were dried to generate aerosol nanoparticles. The size, concentration and morphology of the aerosol particles were evaluated by in-line measurements using an aerosol measuring device and off-line measurements based on the collection of the aerosol particles. After examining the effects of the conditions for the suspensions and the aerosol generation, we were able to obtain NiO and C60 aerosol nanoparticles with average diameters of 53-64 and 88-98 nm, respectively. By feeding these aerosols into a whole-body exposure chamber for rats, a stable supply of the aerosol nanoparticles could be achieved for long hourly durations (6 h per day) as well as for long terms (5 days per week for 4 weeks).

jtL6ZvR5.title: Gene expression profiles in rat lung after inhalation exposure to C60 fullerene particles.
jtL6ZvR5.abstract: Concern over the influence of nanoparticles on human health has risen due to advances in the development of nanotechnology. We are interested in the influence of nanoparticles on the pulmonary system at a molecular level. In this study, gene expression profiling of the rat lung after whole-body inhalation exposure to C(60) fullerene (0.12mg/m(3); 4.1x10(4) particles/cm(3), 96nm diameter) and ultrafine nickel oxide (Uf-NiO) particles (0.2mg/m(3); 9.2x10(4) particles/cm(3), 59nm diameter) as a positive control were employed to gain insights into these molecular events. In response to C(60) fullerene exposure for 6h a day, for 4 weeks (5 days a week), C(60) fullerene particles were located in alveolar epithelial cells at 3 days post-exposure and engulfed by macrophages at both 3 days and 1 month post-exposures. Gene expression profiles revealed that few genes involved in the inflammatory response, oxidative stress, apoptosis, and metalloendopeptidase activity were up-regulated at both 3 days and 1 month post-exposure. Only some genes associated with the immune system process, including major histocompatibility complex (MHC)-mediated immunity were up-regulated. These results were significantly different from those of Uf-NiO particles which induced high expression of genes associated with chemokines, oxidative stress, and matrix metalloproteinase 12 (Mmp12), suggesting that Uf-NiO particles lead to acute inflammation for the inhalation exposure period, and the damaged tissues were repaired in the post-exposure period. We suggest that C(60) fullerene might not have a severe pulmonary toxicity under the inhalation exposure condition.

ilCsVXz8.title: Synthesis and characterization of plasma-polymerized hexamethyldisiloxane films
ilCsVXz8.abstract: The deposition rates of plasma-polymerized (pp-) films from hexamethyldisiloxane (HMDSO) monomer were determined by the quartz crystal microbalance technique. Using the several polymerization conditions for HMDSO, these were found that the deposition rates were proportional to the polymerization time. The deposition rate of the pp-HMDSO films increased with the increasing RF power. But for vapor pressure, the deposition rates increased with increasing the vapor pressure until 100 Pa; above it, deposition rates tended to decrease gradually. The maximum deposition rate of pp-HMDSO film was obtained 4.577 μg/min on 150 W of RF power at 100 Pa of monomer pressure.

w6TYb08w.title: Gene Expression Profiling for Toxicological Assessment of Manufactured Nanoparticles in Rat Lung

vn6dV5vg.title: Expression of inflammation-related cytokines following intratracheal instillation of nickel oxide nanoparticles.
vn6dV5vg.abstract: The objective of this study was to examine what kinds of cytokines are related to lung disorder by well-dispersed nanoparticles. The mass median diameter of nickel oxide in distilled water was 26 nm. Rats intratracheally received 0.2 mg of nickel oxide suspended in distilled water, and were sacrificed from three days to six months. The concentrations of 21 cytokines including inflammation, fibrosis and allergy-related ones were measured in the lung. Infiltration of alveolar macrophages was observed persistently in the nickel oxide-exposed group. Expression of macrophage inflammatory protein-1alpha showed a continued increase in lung tissue and broncho-alveolar lavage fluid (BALF) while interleukin-1alpha (IL-1alpha), IL-1beta in lung tissue and monocyte chemotactic protein-1 in BALF showed transient increases. Taken together, it was suggested that nano-agglomerates of nickel oxide nanoparticles have a persistent inflammatory effect, and the transient increase in cytokine expression and persistent increases in CC chemokine were involved in the persistent pulmonary inflammation.

xcp5tbkK.title: Pulmonary toxicity of well-dispersed cerium oxide nanoparticles following intratracheal instillation and inhalation.
xcp5tbkK.abstract: We performed inhalation and intratracheal instillation studies of cerium dioxide (CeO2) nanoparticles in order to investigate their pulmonary toxicity, and observed pulmonary inflammation not only in the acute and but also in the chronic phases. In the intratracheal instillation study, F344 rats were exposed to 0.2 mg or 1 mg of CeO2 nanoparticles. Cell analysis and chemokines in bronchoalveolar lavage fluid (BALF) were analyzed from 3 days to 6 months following the instillation. In the inhalation study, rats were exposed to the maximum concentration of inhaled CeO2 nanoparticles (2, 10 mg/m(3), respectively) for 4 weeks (6 h/day, 5 days/week). The same endpoints as in the intratracheal instillation study were examined from 3 days to 3 months after the end of the exposure. The intratracheal instillation of CeO2 nanoparticles caused a persistent increase in the total and neutrophil number in BALF and in the concentration of cytokine-induced neutrophil chemoattractant (CINC)-1, CINC-2, chemokine for neutrophil, and heme oxygenase-1 (HO-1), an oxidative stress marker, in BALF during the observation time. The inhalation of CeO2 nanoparticles also induced a persistent influx of neutrophils and expression of CINC-1, CINC-2, and HO-1 in BALF. Pathological features revealed that inflammatory cells, including macrophages and neutrophils, invaded the alveolar space in both studies. Taken together, the CeO2 nanoparticles induced not only acute but also chronic inflammation in the lung, suggesting that CeO2 nanoparticles have a pulmonary toxicity that can lead to irreversible lesions.

vTunnyZn.title: Inflammogenic effect of well-characterized fullerenes in inhalation and intratracheal instillation studies.
vTunnyZn.abstract: We used fullerenes, whose dispersion at the nano-level was stabilized by grinding in nitrogen gas in an agitation mill, to conduct an intratracheal instillation study and an inhalation exposure study. Fullerenes were individually dispersed in distilled water including 0.1% Tween 80, and the diameter of the fullerenes was 33 nm. These suspensions were directly injected as a solution in the intratracheal instillation study. The reference material was nickel oxide in distilled water. Wistar male rats intratracheally received a dose of 0.1 mg, 0.2 mg, or 1 mg of fullerenes and were sacrificed after 3 days, 1 week, 1 month, 3 months, and 6 months. In the inhalation study, Wistar rats were exposed to fullerene agglomerates (diameter: 96 +/- 5 nm; 0.12 +/- 0.03 mg/m3; 6 hours/days for 5 days/week) for 4 weeks and were sacrificed at 3 days, 1 month, and 3 months after the end of exposure. The inflammatory responses and gene expression of cytokine-induced neutrophil chemoattractants (CINCs) were examined in rat lungs in both studies.In the intratracheal instillation study, both the 0.1 mg and 0.2 mg fullerene groups did not show a significant increase of the total cell and neutrophil count in BALF or in the expression of CINC-1,-2alphabeta and-3 in the lung, while the high-dose, 1 mg group only showed a transient significant increase of neutrophils and expression of CINC-1,-2alphabeta and -3. In the inhalation study, there were no increases of total cell and neutrophil count in BALF, CINC-1,-2alphabeta and-3 in the fullerene group.These data in intratracheal instillation and inhalation studies suggested that well-dispersed fullerenes do not have strong potential of neutrophil inflammation.

VAjBG5Io.title: Pulmonary toxicity of well-dispersed titanium dioxide nanoparticles following intratracheal instillation
VAjBG5Io.abstract: In order to investigate the pulmonary toxicity of titanium dioxide (TiO) nanoparticles, we performed an intratracheal instillation study with rats of well-dispersed TiO nanoparticles and examined the pulmonary inflammation and histopathological changes in the lung. Wistar Hannover rats were intratracheally administered 0.2 mg (0.66 mg/kg) and 1.0 mg (3.3 mg/kg) of well-dispersed TiO nanoparticles (P90; diameter of agglomerates: 25 nm), then the pulmonary inflammation responses were examined from 3 days to 6 months after the instillation, and the pathological features were examined up to 24 months. Transient inflammation and the upregulation of chemokines in the broncho-alveolar lavage fluid were observed for 1 month. No respiratory tumors or severe fibrosis were observed during the recovery time. These data suggest that transient inflammation induced by TiO may not lead to chronic, irreversible legions in the lung, and that TiO nanoparticles may not have a high potential for lung disorder.
